description: From Middle English broken, from Old English brocen, ġebrocen, from Proto-Germanic *brukanaz, past participle of Proto-Germanic *brekaną (“to break”). Cognate with Dutch gebroken (“broken”), German Low German broken (“broken”), German gebrochen (“broken”).

adjectives.description: broken (comparative more broken, superlative most broken)

entries.meaning: (of a bone or body part) Fractured; having the bone in pieces.
examples: the ground was littered with broken bones
One recent morning the team had to replace a broken weather research station.
A dog bit my leg and now the skin is broken.

entries.meaning: (of a line) Dashed; made up of short lines with small gaps between each one and the next.
(meteorology, of the sky) Five-eighths to seven-eighths obscured by clouds; incompletely covered by clouds.
(of a melody) Having periods of silence scattered throughout; not regularly continuous.
(of a promise, etc) Breached; violated; not kept.
(of an electronic connection) Disconnected, no longer open or carrying traffic.

examples: This is the most broken application I've seen in a long time.

entries.meaning: (of language) Grammatically non-standard, especially as a result of being produced by a non-native speaker.
(colloquial, US, of a situation) Not having gone in the way intended; saddening.
examples: Oh man! That is just broken!

entries.meaning: (of a person) Completely defeated and dispirited; shattered; destroyed.
examples: The bankruptcy and divorce, together with the death of his son, left him completely broken.

entries.meaning: (sports and gaming, of a tactic or option) Overpowered; overly powerful; too powerful.
